title: Simon Brown (footballer, born 1983)
text:
Simon Alexander Brown (born 18 September 1983) is an English <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who plays for <a href="Chasetown%20F.C.">Chasetown</a> as a midfielder.
He started his career with <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> and was <a href="loan%20%28association%20football%29">loaned</a> out to <a href="Kidderminster%20Harriers%20F.C.">Kidderminster Harriers</a> twice in <a href="Football%20League%20Two">League Two</a>, before joining <a href="Mansfield%20Town%20F.C.">Mansfield Town</a>. Here, he scored a <a href="hat-trick%23Association%20football">hat-trick</a> in 14 minutes, which was the fastest in the history of the club. He was released by Mansfield following their relegation to the <a href="Conference%20Premier">Conference Premier</a> and he signed for <a href="Wrexham%20A.F.C.">Wrexham</a> in 2008.
Career.
Born in <a href="Wednesbury">Wednesbury</a>, West Midlands, Brown grew up as an <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> supporter. He was <a href="education">educated</a> at <a href="Wood%20Green%20High%20School">Wood Green High School</a> and while playing <a href="association%20football">football</a> for their school side, he was spotted by <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> and was signed on by the club at the age of 11. He signed professional terms with the club in July 2003. He joined <a href="Football%20League%20Two">League Two</a> side <a href="Kidderminster%20Harriers%20F.C.">Kidderminster Harriers</a> on <a href="loan%20%28football%29">loan</a> in March 2004, where he impressed on his debut in a 1–1 draw against <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>. He returned to West Brom in May 2004, having scored twice in eight appearances at Kidderminster. He went to Kidderminster on loan for a second time in July 2004 and made 14 appearances before breaking a bone in his leg in October 2004. He made one more appearance for Kidderminster in the following month and then joined <a href="Mansfield%20Town%20F.C.">Mansfield Town</a> in December 2004 on an 18-month contract for an initial <a href="fee">fee</a> of £50,000 and made 21 appearances in the remainder of the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20in%20English%20football">2004–05</a> season for Mansfield, scoring two goals.
Brown had a fine <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20in%20English%20football">2005–06</a> season and was Mansfield's second leading scorer behind <a href="Richard%20Barker%20%28footballer%20born%201975%29">Richie Barker</a> with 12 goals before his season was ended by a <a href="hernia">hernia</a> operation in April 2006. He was offered a new contract in July 2006 and made 40 appearances in the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20in%20English%20football">2006–07</a> season, scoring five goals. He was offered a further contract in May 2007 and in November scored a <a href="hat-trick%23Association%20football">hat-trick</a> in 14 minutes, the fastest in the club's history, as Mansfield beat <a href="Macclesfield%20Town%20F.C.">Macclesfield Town</a> 5–0, which earned him a place in the League Two team of the week. After Mansfield Town were <a href="promotion%20and%20relegation">relegated</a> to the <a href="Conference%20Premier">Conference Premier</a> at the end of the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20in%20English%20football">2007–08</a> season, he was released by the club. Brown had made over 120 appearances in all competitions for Mansfield. He joined newly relegated Conference Premier side <a href="Wrexham%20A.F.C.">Wrexham</a> in June 2008 on a two-year contract. In November 2008 he joined <a href="Rushden%20%26amp%3B%20Diamonds%20F.C.">Rushden & Diamonds</a> on loan until January 2009. He made his debut in a 4–0 victory over <a href="Altrincham%20F.C.">Altrincham</a> and returned to Wrexham following the expiry of the loan on 5 January, making three appearances for Rushden.
He was involved in a controversy when he wrote a message on the Facebook profile of Wrexham teammate <a href="Christian%20Smith%20%28footballer%29">Christian Smith</a>, which regarded <a href="Wes%20Baynes">Wes Baynes</a>'s contract situation at the club, and caused an angry reaction by the fans. Following the completion of his loan spell at Rushden, he was set to join <a href="York%20City%20F.C.">York City</a> on loan. The move was completed on 15 January, when he signed for the rest of the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20in%20English%20football">2008–09</a> season. He made his debut in a 3–0 victory against <a href="Lewes%20F.C.">Lewes</a> on 17 January as a right midfielder. He featured as a striker as part of a <a href="formation%20%28association%20football%29%234%E2%80%933%E2%80%933">4-3-3</a> formation in a 1–1 draw with <a href="Altrincham%20F.C.">Altrincham</a> on 27 January. He joined <a href="Tamworth%20F.C.">Tamworth</a> on a month's loan on 13 November, making nine appearances before returning to Wrexham in January 2010. On 11 March 2010, he was released from his contract at Wrexham by mutual consent after failing to make a first team appearance for the club all season. He later joined <a href="Eastwood%20Town%20F.C.">Eastwood Town</a> and made his debut in a 2–1 defeat to <a href="Workington%20A.F.C.">Workington</a>.
